choices.C: Local database users who use this database link should have accounts and the required privileges in the remote database.
choices.E: Only the user creating the database link must have an account and the required privileges in the remote database.
choices.A: The GLOBAL_NAMES initialization parameter should be set to FALSE in the ORCL database.
choices.D: The REMOTE_OS_AUTHENT initialization parameter should be set to FALSE in the remote database.
choices.B: The SALES1 net service name should be known to both the local and remote databases.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
GLOBAL_NAMES specifies whether a database link is required to have the same name as the database to which it connects.

If the value of GLOBAL_NAMES is false, then no check is performed. If you use or plan to use distributed processing, then Oracle recommends that you set this parameter to true to ensure the use of consistent naming conventions for databases and links in a networked environment.

I think AC is correct 
Ref - https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/SQLRF/statements_5006.htm#SQLRF01205

If you omit both of those clauses (CONNECT TO user IDENTIFIED BY password / CONNECT TO CURRENT_USER), then the database link connects to the remote database as the locally connected user.

questions.question_text: Which three are activities performed by SMON? (Choose three.)

choices.B: applying online redo during instance recovery
choices.D: performing database services registration with the default listener
choices.F: recovering failed transactions that were skipped during instance recovery because of file-read or tablespace offline errors
choices.E: restarting a server or a dispatcher process that terminated abnormally
choices.A: cleaning up the database buffer cache and freeing resources that a client process was using
choices.C: cleaning up temporary segments that are no longer needed

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BCF
system monitor process (SMON)
The background process in charge of a variety of system-level cleanup duties, including instance recovery, recovering terminated transactions that were skipped during instance recovery, Cleaning up unused temporary segments, and Coalescing contiguous free extents within dictionary-managed tablespaces.

questions.question_text: Which two categories of segments are analyzed by the Automatic Segment Advisor? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/ADMIN/schema.htm#ADMIN-GUID-918AD789-47B8-4B11-9016-184D1B0D9AD4
The Automatic Segment Advisor does not analyze every database object. Instead, it examines database statistics, samples segment data, and then selects the following objects to analyze:
 Tablespaces that have exceeded a critical or warning space threshold
 Segments that have the most activity
 Segments that have the highest growth rate

choices.E: segments for tables created using ADVANCED ROW COMPRESSION
choices.B: segments that have the highest growth rate in a database
choices.A: segments in tablespaces that have exceeded a critical or warning space threshold
choices.C: segments that are sparsely populated and have more than 10% of free space below the high water mark.
by implementing Database Resource Manager and assign it a profile for the user
choices.D: by implementing Database Resource Manager and assign it a role for the user
choices.E: by using appropriate KERNEL parameters set in the profile assigned to the user
choices.A: by alerting the appropriate user attributes with an ALTER USER command
choices.B: by using appropriate PASSWORD parameters set in the profile assigned to the user

questions.question_text:
A user establishes a connection to a database instance by using an Oracle Net.
You want to ensure that:
1. The user account must be locked after five consecutive unsuccessful login attempts.
2. Data read per session must be limited for the user.
3. The user cannot have more than three simultaneous sessions.
4. The user must have a maximum of 10 minutes session idle time before being logged off automatically.
Which two would you do to implement this? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
BE:
you can accomplish all 4 resource limit restrictions by changing the PASSWORD and the KERNEL parameters set in the profile assigned to the user. LOGICAL_READS_PER_CALL and SESSIONS_PER_USER are examples of KERNEL parameters in a profile.

AD is correct. Tricky question.
Resource management can be done with PROFILE and not ROLE. However, to update a PROFILE, a proper role should be assigned to the user that has the ALTER PROFILE privilege. I believe that is the reason D should be correct. If the option for D wasn't provided, then we could choose PROFILE option (C).

comments.content: Sorry, this solution for B and E
Sorry, this solution for B and C

discussion.content:
AD correct

https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/SQLRF/statements_6012.htm#SQLRF01310

Use the CREATE PROFILE statement to create a profile, which is a set of limits on database resources. If you ASSIGN (ALTER USER) the profile to a user, then that user cannot exceed these limits.

1. FAILED_LOGIN_ATTEMPTS 
2. LOGICAL_READS_PER_SESSION 
3. SESSIONS_PER_USER 
4. IDLE_TIME

comments.content:
B,E
Resource manager will implement to all user, not the user.

I am considering B,E since Resource Manager cannot handle the (1) login failure.
But I also doubt Kernel can handle (2) read data?

For D, assign to a role, can't the users unset the role?
I think assign to a profile is better. 
B,C

discussion.content: This should be BD. You can use the profile to make sure the password parameters are enforced... and use Resource Manager to limit resource usage

choices.B: The user Sidney can connect to the database instance but cannot perform sort operations because no space quota is specified for the temp tablespace.
choices.D: The user Sidney can connect to the database instance but requires relevant privileges to create objects in the users tablespace.
choices.E: The user Sidney is created and authenticated by the operating system.
choices.C: The user Sidney is created but cannot connect to the database instance because no profile is default.
choices.A: The create user command fails if any role with the name Sidney exists in the database.
